docs.lead_paragraph: How did a homeless woman end up buying a house in Queens with no down payment and a mortgage bill that was multiples of what she earned each month?

headline.main: Homeless? Low-Paying Job? Her Mortgage Was Approved

docs.abstract: A homeless woman who bought a house in Queens was among the witnesses at the Commission of Investigation's public hearings on the subprime lending crisis and mortgage fraud.
docs.snippet: A homeless woman who bought a house in Queens was among the witnesses at the Commission of Investigation's public hearings on the subprime lending crisis and mortgage fraud.

docs.lead_paragraph: Only three weeks after presenting its budget, Gov. Eliot Spitzer's administration is lowering projections for tax revenue by $384 million, because of increasingly ominous reports of distress on Wall Street and in the nation's economy, Danny Hakim reports. To keep the budget in balance, the governor is proposing several new spending cuts, including further paring back increases in Medicaid reimbursements and dipping into the state's environmental protection fund. While the changes represent a fraction of New York's $124 billion budget, they are a sign of how rapidly shifting economic forecasts are causing havoc with the state's fiscal planning. It is rare for a governor to second-guess his own budget, especially so soon after releasing it.
docs.abstract: Also in the Morning Buzz: the (possibly short-lived) proliferation of twins in city neighborhoods, the efforts of vendors in the Moore Street Retail Market in Brooklyn to keep the market open and the lengths to which some motorists will go to avoid paying E-Z Pass tolls.
